docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials say the pain reliever in Aleve may be safer on the heart than other popular anti-inflammatory drugs taken by millions of Americans.

headline.main: FDA: Aleve May Be Safer on Heart Than Rival Drugs
headline.print_headline: FDA: Aleve May Be Safer on Heart Than Rival Drugs

docs.snippet: Federal health officials say the pain reliever in Aleve may be safer on the heart than other popular anti-inflammatory drugs taken by millions of Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists, looking for new weapons against insect pests in farming, have developed gene-silencing agents. But skeptics are concerned about potential threats to nontarget insects and even humans.

headline.main: Genetic Weapon Against Insects Raises Hope and Fear in Farming
headline.print_headline: Genetic Weapon Against Insects Raises Hope and Fear in Farming

docs.abstract: Scientists and biotechnology companies are developing a new technique to kill pests without harming beneficial insects, one that relies on RNA inference, natural phenomenon that is set off by double-stranded RNA; some specialists fear that releasing gene-silencing agents into fields could harm organisms that have a common genetic makeup to targeted pests, and possibly even humans.
docs.snippet: Scientists, looking for new weapons against insect pests in farming, have developed gene-silencing agents. But skeptics are concerned about potential threats to nontarget insects and even humans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight.
docs.abstract: Sending humans into space for long periods of time poses litany of health problems, from swollen head and atrophied limbs to exposure to radiation; proposed NASA mission to send astronauts to Mars some time after 2030, trip that would take 2.5 years, or nearly six time current standard tour, has scientists racing to find solutions.
docs.snippet: Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Arizona moved Monday to implement new abortion rules limiting the use of the most common abortion-inducing drug and requiring doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospitals.

headline.main: New Arizona Rules Would Limits Abortion Drug Use
headline.print_headline: New Arizona Rules Would Limits Abortion Drug Use

docs.snippet: Arizona moved Monday to implement new abortion rules limiting the use of the most common abortion-inducing drug and requiring doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospitals.

headline.main: Helping Smokers Quit, or Not Start in the First Place

docs.abstract: Images on television and the availability of electronic cigarettes are among the temptations that attract new smokers and weaken the willpower of those who want to quit.
docs.snippet: Images on television and the availability of electronic cigarettes are among the temptations that attract new smokers and weaken the willpower of those who want to quit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking stock 30 years after the powerful story of a severe schizophrenic was told.

headline.main: For the Mentally Ill, It’s Worse
headline.print_headline: For the Mentally Ill, It’s Worse

docs.abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column welcomes Vintage Books decision to reissue Is There No Place on Earth for Me?, Pulitzer Prize-winning 1981 work by Susan Sheehan that told story of a severe schizophrenic; holds thirty years later, despite trend toward deinstitutionalization, treatment of the mentally ill still has a long way to go.
docs.snippet: Taking stock 30 years after the powerful story of a severe schizophrenic was told.
